comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Possibly outside Hyne's Pub, corner of Gloucester Place and Railway Street. sometime on or after 5th Feb 1921.........Ryan's assassination. Streetview OSI It can be seen on the OSI map that the house three up from the corner has a railing out front. This would tie with the Hogan photograph with the damaged corners.

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: This photo was the basis of a Mick O'Dea painting

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] So fantastically well done! This photo, called in our catalogue as Black and Tans at L.N.W. Hotel, Dublin (HOGW 1) is printed in the Irish Independent on Monday, 7 February 1921, page 3:
Auxiliaries outside the public house in Gloucester St., Dublin, in which a military policeman was shot dead. -Hogan
And in the same edition of the Irish Independent on Monday, 7 February 1921, page 5:
Corporal Ryan, a military policeman, was killed in a bar in Old Gloucester Pl. on Sat. morning [Saturday 5 February], his assailants - 3 men who entered the bar - escaping. He was in civilian garb at the time.
So we've not only found the date and location for today's posted photograph, but others in our Hogan-Wilson Collection! As the shooting was on Saturday morning, and the many newspaper reports tell of much Auxiliary to-ing and fro-ing, I'm thinking we're safe enough to go with Saturday, 5 February 1921 as the date?? Or to be really safe Saturday 5th or Sunday 6th February?? What think ye? Can't thank you all enough!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content:
Excellent work [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03/] and a nice find by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00/]. If that location is correct the sun is coming more or less due south at the time the photo was taken so I think we can safely say c. 12 noon, Saturday 5th February 1921.

I had initially thought the shadows were too long for it to be southern light but at that time of year the angle of sun would have been quite low at midday.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: OK, great! ... and, for completeness, were they Black & Tans or Auxiliaries?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
R.I.C. reservists, weren't they?

It's how the garda reserve will end up, mark my words. They start off just processing speeding tickets and before you know it they're hanging around pubs brandishing machine guns and burning down half of Cork!

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: Balack & Tans and Auxiliaries often confused - newspaper reports refer to Auxiliary Police only!

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: House No.19

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/48236157@N02] When I posed the question I was hoping for an intelligent, historical perspective – hadn’t anticipated the expletive and reference to an Australian’s imagination.  Your contribution to the uncovering of Ireland’s history is …er… monumental!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] Well according to Wikipedia (that hotbed of the australian imaginative perspective, I know), "The Black and Tans should not be confused with the Auxiliary Division, which was a counter-insurgency unit of the RIC made up of former British officers. However, sometimes the term "Black and Tans" is used to cover both of these groups".

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Oh, and well done Beanie for finding the location.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] In fact, the Wiki article makes them sound like some sort of British Freikorps. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_and_Tans

comment.author: 34574252@N02
comment._content: Tam O'Shanter, shoes, trousers - definitely an Auxiliary

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/48236157@N02] Hi John. I deleted your earlier comments. As [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] says, we don't use expletives here. We have photographs from a lot of contentious periods in Irish history, and we discuss them from every angle, but hopefully never in a dismissive way. We probably all have our own political and historical baggage, but we leave that piled up outside the door...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: Sorry about the expletive? But I don't think that there was much difference between the Black and Tans and the Auxiliary!
